title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: 50-yard-drive-pub-proves-costly-north-berwick-man
story: Andrew Watt, , was pulled over by police officers at the townrsquos High Street on November , .He was breathalysed and the reading showed he had mg of alcohol in ml of breath, more than double the legal limit of mg.Wattrsquos solicitor Cameron Tait said that his client had been having a business meeting at a pub in the town when his colleague was called away unexpectedly.Mr Tait said Watt had consumed ldquotwo beers and had started on a third when he decided to head home after the meeting came to an early close.Edinburgh Sherf Court heard that police officers then pulled Watt over due to his vehicle having a ldquofaulty brake light after he had only driven  yards.The court also heard of a second incident where police were called out to Wattrsquos home on the townrsquos Keppel Road on July  last year.Two officers had cause to speak to Watt about a possible road traffic offence and he was said to have pushed the officers away from him.The police managed to ldquogain control of the accused and he was taken into a marked police vehicle.While in the vehicle, Watt was asked about the identity of the driver of one of his workrsquos vans earlier that day and he was said to have simply replied ldquono.Lawyer Mr Tait said that Watt had been walking into his home when the officers ldquobarged into his property.He was askedhe had been driving a vehicle that day, which he denied. Watt then carried out a drink-drive breath test which he subsequently failed.Mr Tait told the court that any driving ban would be ldquodevastating to the business owner and that he had  employees and needed his licence to get to jobs and for pricing jobs in the evening.Sherf Peter McCormack heard that Watt also had a previous conviction for drink-driving from  and, due to him committing the same offence within  years, he had no option but to issue a y road ban.Watt was banned from driving for three years and fined a total of pound.The sherf allowed Watt to take part in a drink-drive rehabilitation scheme whichsuccessfully completed would see the ban reduced by a quarter.Watt was also fined pound to mark the offence with the police at his home last year.His not guilty plea to the second drink-drive offence was accepted by the Crown.Watt pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at High Street, North Berwick, on November , .He also pleaded guilty to resisting arrest and failing to give the officers the name and date of birth of the driver of a vehicle at Keppel Road, North Berwick, on July  last year.

title: haddington-youngsters-recipe-book-helping-community-kitchen-project
story: Pupils at the townrsquos Compass School came up with the idea of collecting recipes from across the school community and publishing them as a recipe book.More than  copies were sold, with the profit of pound donated to Our Community Kitchen, which is based at the townrsquos bowling club.Earlier this month, the schoolrsquos pupil council was delighted to be able to hand over a cheque to Elaine Gale, from Our Community Kitchen.The charityrsquos aim is to bring people who are socially isolated from throughout the Haddington and Lammermuir area together to share home-cooked food in a relaxed and friendly environment, allowing for friendships to form.There are no barriers to age or ability, all are welcome.Ms Gale told the children more about the work of the charity on her visit to the school and thanked the school community for their support and generosity.Mark Becher, headteacher at the school, on Haddingtonrsquos West Road, was ldquoabsolutely delighted with the support the initiative received.He said: ldquoOur pupil council became aware of the work of the charity, particularly during the first lockdown when they ed to school, they wished to include the charity alongside those others which we choose to assist each year.ldquoWe received a fantastic response from the school community for recipes to be included in the book: from home-baking ideas to casseroles from soups to desserts.ldquoThe resulting publication proved to be very popular and,you can forgive the pun, sold like hot cakes!ldquoWe would like to publicly thank everyone who helped us and purchased a copy of the book.ldquoThrough their support, we have been able to raise a signicant amount for this important charity and support their invaluable work in the local community.

title: applications-open-funding-north-berwick-golf-clubs-community-fund
story: Since the fund was set up in , the club has received  applications and has helped  local organisations with more than pound, of support.The Firth of Forth Lobster Hatchery, East Lothian Yacht Club, Law Primary School, Coastal Communities Museum and North Berwick Community Council are among those to have benefited.A club spokesperson said: ldquoGiven the current climate, the club would like to continue to support local organisations. Having the ability to improve the lives of others within the local community is a privilege and one that comes with its own sense of obligation.ldquoFor many local organisations, small donations can make a startling dference to their ability to serve the community and continue the excellent work they do.ldquoWe believe thatwe can in some way benefit local organisations, it can help cement their future helping the community. One of our overarching aims it to build a lasting legacy in the local area.Those interested in applying should email feedback@northberwickgolf club for an application form.

title: cinema-tranents-fraser-centre-reopens-film-fans
story: The centre, on Winton Place, was refurbished in  and reopened in November of that year.But along with several other venues across the county, it was forced to close in March last year due to lockdown. It had only been able to host a few screenings before then.As most of Scotlandrsquos restrictions eased last month, which included cinemas being able to reopen and resume business, those at The Fraser Centre were planning theof its screenings.People visiting the centrersquos -capacity cinema will see a slight change as handrails have been added to the staircase that leads to seats positioned higher up, following requests from the publicAmong the movies planned in the coming weeks is the new James Bond film No Time To Die.All tickets are pound plus a booking fee per ticket, a special offer to celebrate the cinema opening once more. This price is available for films up to October . Tickets are non-refundable and can be booked at thefrasercentre films-live-eventsThere is limited capacity for all screenings, with social distancing in place. Facemasks must be worn by anyone aged over five unless they are exempt or eating drinking.It already held some screenings last week and there are more to come.On Thursday , The Last Bus is screened at pm.Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings is shown on Saturdayat pm, with Respect, a film about Aretha Franklin starring Jenner Hudson, following at pm.No Time To Die, Daniel Craigrsquos final outing as famous spy James Bond, is screened on October  at pm and pm, and again on October  at pm tickets pound .A thank you was shared to all of The Fraser Centrersquos sponsors and its programming partners INDY Cinema Group.David Orr, manager for The Fraser Centre Community Trust, said: ldquoWe are excited to introduce our cinema programme in The Fraser Centre.ldquoWith the venue on the site of the townrsquos old picture house, we have always planned to reintroduce cinema as part of our new award-winning building and we are delighted to share our opening programme for everyone to enjoy.Those interested in joining the cinema volunteer team are asked to visit thefrasercentre careers, volunteereastlothian.org.uk or call  . Weekend and midweek opportunities are available.

title: letter-week-not-impressed-number-campervans-north-berwick-seafront
story: This leaves no parking for anyone driving down there at the weekend andyou want to go onto the sand at the bottom of the steps by the water treatment plant, you have to cut through tables and chairs set up for their free holiday.Last weekend, there were  units parked up in a fairly small area, yet, being a campervan owner, I am fully aware that on a caravan site they have to keep you six metres apart to comply with fire regulations.One hopes East Lothian Council intervenes before something terrible happens.The motorhomes are often less than one metre apart, with fire pits and campfires set up each evening.On a visit to Ruby Bay in Fe recently, they had a large parking area for about  vehicles with seven designated for overnight parking on a first-come, first-served basis. This ensures that anyone staying overnight has sufficient space and seems like a sensible and proactive measure.The parking in Fe also had a public toilet: I can only hope that all of the campers in North Berwick are taking all of the contents of their toilet cassette and dirty dishwater home to be emptied there and that nothing is being dumped at the beach.We have a sign displayed here stating lsquoNo Overnight Parkingrsquo but this is a token gesture, as all motorhome owners know that this is not legally enforceable.I would like to see a change being made to ensure that the area is safe and for use by overnight tourists, day tourists and locals.Name and address suppliedAn East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWorking with our partners, we continue to actively consider action to support the responsible use of public land. This is important given the popularity of lsquostaycationsrsquo and the large number of visitors coming to East Lothian. In the meantime, we would encourage anyone who encounters vehicles parked in an unsafe way on the public road to make the authorities aware by contacting the police on .

title: families-remember-ancestors-lost-lives-sea-130-years-ago
story: Cousins and former pupils of Musselburgh Grammar School Jim Ritchie Johnston, , a Musselburgh resident, and Stuart Ritchie, , who now lives in Markinch, Fe, met at Fisherrow Harbour to remember their great grandfather James Ritchie.He drowned at the age of  after Star of the East was shipwrecked at the entrance to Lowestoft Harbour on November , , after the crew of eight set off from Fisherrow on September  that year.They were joined at a poignant family harbourside gathering by Mr Johnstonrsquos son Keith, a Musselburgh resident, and Mr Ritchiersquos sons Scottand Craig .Musselburgh resident Peter Millarrsquos great grandfatherrsquos brother John Williamson, a -year-old fisherman, also lost his le in the fishing tragedy.The boatrsquos skipper Walter Brown, aged , drowned as did his sons Walter, aged , and -year-old James, Alexander Brown, , and Robert Dickson, .The sole survivor of the tragedy was James Bonthron who reportedly clung to a piece of wreckage and was deaf from that time on.Simon Fairnie, of Musselburgh Museum, has researched the loss of The Star.He said: ldquoMany fishermen were lost at sea in the old days of sailing: one reason being that the herring fishing season occurred in early autumn and early winter when storms and gales were frequent.The  season had been patchy, with catches from September disappointing and the men of the Star of the East ndash a Fie which was a boat popular with the Fisherrow men ndash decided to try their luck further south.On November , explained Mr Fairnie, the fishing boat left Lowestoft for the fishing grounds and hauled about  barrels of herring before sailing for port at midnight.He said: ldquoBy .am a gale had reached its height and a wary approach was made to harbour.ldquoLowestoft in those days was regarded as dangerous to navigate. There were two lighthouses at the harbour entrance: one on a northern clf and the other to the south. These were intended to guide vessels through the portrsquos channel which had dangerous sand banks on either side.ldquoBut heavy rain prevented The Starrsquos crew from seeing the lights properly and there was a breakwater to be avoided before the harbour could be taken.ldquoOn entering the port, a huge wave bore down on the boat, threatening to throw it onto the breakwater.ldquoThe crew took what evasive action they could but, sadly, the boat was dashed against the masonry pier with such force that she quickly broke up with the tragic loss of all the crew but one.An active search was made but none of the bodies were reportedly found at that time.Almost five months later, the body of the skipper was found by fisherman William Cross, washed ashore at Dunwich, on March , .Newspapers reported at the time of memorial services being held in Musselburgh and visits made to grief-stricken families by the provost.Stuart Ritchie said it was believed that the skipperrsquos body was the only one found.He said: ldquoAfter a good deal of searching over a period of time, recently I found my great grandfatherrsquos death certicate. I feel very sad that, apparently, Jamesrsquos body was never found so a funeral may never have taken place.But he added: ldquoIt is good that the descendants are meeting up.ldquoIt would be even betterthe wider community in the Musselburgh Fisherrow area was made aware of this heritage and perhaps the local authority could do a bit to help here.He felt a lasting memorial to the crew of Star of the East at Fisherrow Harbour would be a fitting tribute to them.Mr Johnston added: ldquoAttending our harbour ceremony felt like stepping back into the past to remember and honour, not only James Ritchie and the other brave men of The Star who lost their lives, but also to allow us today to pay tribute to every family within the Fisherrow fishing community for the important contribution it has made to the economy and history of Musselburgh over many years.Walter Brown jnrrsquos great grandson Walter Moffat, , who lives in Toronto, Canada, visited the skipper Walter Brown snrrsquos grave at Dunwich in early  where a memorial stone had been placed by his widow Jane lsquoBonthronrsquo Brown.He said his ancestor was seen by commanding everyone to ldquosave themselves as he held the mast going down with the ship.ldquoCoincidentally, Walter Brown jnr forgot to take his bible on that trip ndash I have it at home, said his descendant who is the grandson of Walter Brown, the son of Walter Brown jr and Elizabeth Brown , who was just one when his father died in the shipwreck.The Scottish Fisheries Museum at Anstruther is planning to mark the th anniversary of the loss of The Star at its annual memorial service in the museumrsquos Memorial Room in October. The ceremony is organised in conjunction with the Fishermenrsquos Mission and is open to relatives of those lost.The names of the crew of The Star who died also look set to be listed in the museumrsquos memorial book which records the names of fishermen lost at sea prior to . Those from  onwards are recorded on brass plaques on the walls.Curator Linda Fitzpatrick said: ldquoThe entries are made at the request of family members and can reflect iniduals or entire crews of boats. They are not a complete record of all losses.ldquoThis ensures that we have the details correct and that we take account of family sensitivities.She added: The dangers of le at sea are all too well known and, often, the tragedy of a sinking was compounded by the fact that the men sailed with their relatives so that a father, husband, brother and son could be lost in a single incident.

title: sight-loss-support-a-blessing-prestonpans-resident-agnes-78
story: Agnes Stevenson, , of Grant Road, received her age-related macular degeneration diagnosis in  when she was a full-time carer for husband Tom, who had dementia and passed away last year.Struggling with the impact of her sight loss, Agnes reached out to the charity Sight Scotland through its newly launched telephone support line ndash she has since praised the community service for helping her feel less alone.The Sight Scotland Support Line, launched across Edinburgh and the Lothians in January as part of the newly formed Family Wellbeing Service which launched last Wednesday, offers people with sight loss and their families someone to turn to for information, advice and support.The retired bookkeeper said: ldquoI didnrsquot know anything about macular degeneration.ldquoWhen I was told I had it, I was devastated.ldquoAt that time, I got no information at all.ldquoIt was a huge shock. If I had had support at an earlier point following my diagnosis, I donrsquot think I would have gone into such a depression.ldquoWhen you hear that your sight is going, you think: lsquoWhat am I going to do  How am I going to manage rsquoldquoYou canrsquot sleep for thinking about how yoursquore going to cope.ldquoI had given up completely. It made me quite depressed, thinking that nothing  could help with my sight.ldquoWhen I contacted Sight Scotland, Irsquod just thought: lsquoI have to do something. I cannot accept this.rsquoldquoThis is the first time I feel I have some support now. There was somebody there who would listen to me. Itrsquos been a blessing.Sight Scotlandrsquos Family Wellbeing Service team has provided emotional support to Agnes as she adapts to le with sight loss, including aiding her in regaining her much-loved sewing hobby.In addition to the telephone service, Sight Scotlandrsquos Family Wellbeing Service also provides the option of face-to-face home visits for people based in East Lothian.The Tranent-born resident said: ldquoOne of the Sight Scotland community workers, Debbie McGregor, has introduced me to dferent options and given me so much confidence. Shersquos been helping me with magniers and explaining how that can help. I see a future for myself and that is thanks to Sight Scotland.ldquoThere must be hundreds of people like me. The Sight Scotland Support Line can be a huge help for people impacted by sight loss.ldquoThere is somebody there for you. You donrsquot need to be alone.Sight Scotlandrsquos latest findings show out of  visually impaired people, more than  per cent said they had not had enough information about where to access support after this diagnosis.More than  per cent said it was important to provide more support to family members and carers.Mark OrsquoDonnell, chief executive of Sight Scotland and Sight Scotland Veterans, said: ldquoWe are proud to officially launch the Sight Scotland Support Line nationally. This new telephone service is there for anyone impacted by visual impairment so that no one in Scotland has to struggle with sight loss alone.People impacted by sight loss can call the Sight Scotland Support Line on   , Monday to Friday, am-pm, or visit SightScotland.org.uk for more information.

title: pick-pumpkin-farm-near-athelstaneford
story: Kilduff Farm, near Athelstaneford, is home to East Lothianrsquos well-loved pumpkin patch, specialising in culinary pumpkins as well as traditional Hallowersquoen ieties.Lucy and Russell Calder, from North Berwick, took over the arable farm from Russellrsquos grandfather in  ndash the farm has been in the Calder family since .They are excited to welcome new and old faces from East Lothian and beyond to pick their own homegrown pumpkins between October  and  at their fourth annual pumpkin festival.The festival is a family affair, as Lucy and Russell were assisted by children Maisie, , Louisa, nine, and Charlie, five, in planting , pumpkin seeds in April.Following a successful period of being cared for in the polytunnels at Kilduff Farm, the pumpkin plants were planted in two patches at the start of June.As well as some of the more commonly known ieties, including Crown Prince, Knuckle Head and the popular Tractor iety, the Calders are trialling some new pumpkin ieties this year, with the likes of Racer, Orange Smoothie and Polar Bear giving more choice for ghostly carving.Lucy said: ldquoA huge amount of planning goes on behind the scenes to prepare for our pumpkin festival and we spend a lot of time praying to the weather gods.ldquoThankfully, this yearrsquos crop is looking really promising and we are so looking forward to sharing our hard work and excitement with lots of people this year.ldquoAfter the year we have all had, we want to add a real festival vibe to The Patch with a few added extras to pack a bit of a punch.The family hope to educate and inspire children about Scottish-grown food.Lucy added: ldquoWersquore really passionate about Scottish farming and highlighting the work which goes on behind the scenes.ldquoPumpkins are just one of many crops we grow but it is a great one to hook childrenrsquos interest and educate them about how food grows and how to cook with pumpkins.ldquoThis is something in which we invest a huge amount of thought with the culinary ieties we grow.ldquoPumpkins are nutritious, delicious and versatile, and we want to reduce the food waste which comes with each Hallowersquoen. Wersquove created a bank of recipes which we hope will inspire people to get creative in the kitchen with their pumpkins.The annual pumpkin festival has been open to the public since  and the Calder family have grown more than , pumpkins this year.Visitors can also visit the pumpkin house for family photos, explore the straw bale maze and look at the resident scarecrows.The Patch remained open to the public last year, but Covid restrictions meant visitor numbers were restricted.This year, food and drink from local businesses Drt and FieldFireFork, Kilduff-grown pumpkins and apples will feature on a menu on offer to visitors. Numbers will be managed in accordance to Covid guidelines.For more information or to book, visit kilduff

title: another-8-000-trees-planted-butterdean-wood
story: Woodland Trust Scotland is extending Butterdean Wood, near Gladsmuir, as part of a -year partnership to plant trees and create new woods across the country.Two open fields have been acquired which will add . hectares to the existing . hectares, enabling , more trees to be planted over the next  months.The community is now being asked to help choose a name for the new extension ndash and there are opportunities to go along to help plant it.Potential names for the extension are: Butterdean Coille Darach, Butterdean Brocksden, Butterdean Paddock, Butterdean Fauld, Butterdean Boar Copse and Butterdean Wolf Copse.Alastair Seaman, Woodland Trust Scotland director, said: ldquoIt will be a marvellous haven for people and wildle but also a carbon store to help in the fight against climate change.The native trees will be planted from autumn through to  with the help of Bank of Scotland colleagues, local schoolchildren and the community.The trees have the potential to absorb up to , tonnes of carbon in their letime.To vote on a name for the new extention, visit emea.focusvision survey selfserve  Voting closes on October .Butterdean Coille Darach is Gaelic for Butterdean Oak Wood Butterdean Brocksden reflects a large and long-established badger sett nearby Butterdean Paddock and Butterdean Fauld acknowledges the ground has been used to graze horses in the past Butterdean Boar Copse and Wolf Copse reflect that boars and wolves were once native to the area.

title: jacquie-bell-elected-chair-dunbar-east-linton-area-partnership
story: Jacquie Bell has succeeded George Robertson, who announced last year that he would be stepping down from Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership .The group, which is led by community volunteers, aims to make a dference locally and address the impacts of poverty.Mrs Bell, who is also secretary of Dunbar Community Council, was looking forward to officially taking on the role from next month.She said: ldquoI want to thank DELAP for electing me as their new community chairperson.ldquoI have been active as a local community volunteer for many years, including working closely with George on co-ordinating the local response to Covid.ldquoI am committed to helping to make Dunbar and East Linton the best it can be for local residents.ldquoI am excited to be taking on the new role and wish to do so in an inclusive way.ldquoI want to ensure that the area partnership hears voices and views from all parts of the ward to ensure that it works to make a dference to the lives of everyone in both Dunbar town and the smaller settlements.Mrs Bell, who has lived in Belhaven since , previously worked as a social worker and has been an active member of the area partnership since it was established.She has been the grouprsquos vice-chairwoman since  and a member of Dunbarrsquos community council for more than  years.She also served as a Liberal Democrat councillor representing the Dunbar and East Linton ward on East Lothian Council from  to .Now, she is looking to build on the work of Mr Robertson, who was chairman of DELAP for three years.During that time, he has overseen a number of projects, including the repainting of some of the building facades on Dunbar High Street, the installation of benches around the area, as well as improvements to some village facilities in Tyninghame, West Barns and Belhaven.During the pandemic, he played a leading role in bringing volunteers together and supported a number of initiatives to help those affected by Covid-.Led by community volunteers, Dunbar and East Linton is one of six area partnerships which receive funding from East Lothian Council to identy local priorities and help reduce inequalities.It is supported by East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities service, which promotes and delivers the councilrsquos community empowerment aims ndash working collaboratively with local communities, other council services, community planning partners such as Police Scotland, NHS, third-sector and community organisations ndash to make a dference locally and address the impacts of poverty.Mr Robertson said: ldquoI am very proud to have been associated with DELAP and all of the positive outcomes we have achieved for our communities, particularly during the past  months of the pandemic.ldquoWe have supported a number of great community initiatives, including food provisions such as the lsquomeals on wheelsrsquo delivery service for people who were shielding.ldquoAs well as providing a cooked meal, this helped tackle social isolation for those unable to see friends and family due to lockdown.ldquoAll across the Dunbar and East Linton area we have seen many improvements through the hard work, dedication and support we received from local communities who are at the forefront of community empowerment.

title: looking-back-sir-john-cope-house-cockenzie
story: He became an army officer and distinguished himself in ious European engagements.In , Cope was promoted to lieutenant-general and, just before the  Rising, he was appointed military commander in Scotland.After Prince Charles and his men had landed at Eriskay, Cope withdrew to Inverness, leaving Edinburgh exposed.The Prince lost no time before he entered the Capital in triumph with his army of Highlanders, rough types who were capable of anything.After Cope had loaded his troops onto ships at Aberdeen and sailed for Dunbar, the two armies met at Prestonpans on September , .Many of Copersquos troops were inexperienced recruits and his officers were a feeble lot.Early the following morning, when the Highlanders charged, Copersquos dragoons fled in panic, leaving the infantry exposed.Had the humane Prince and his officers not interceded, a bloodbath might well have have ensued, with no prisoners taken.The craven Cope fled to Berwick-upon-Tweed with some of his officers and a rabble of surviving soldiers.He faced a court martial but was exonerated, the cowardly conduct of the soldiers being blamed for everything.He obtained another appointment as Governor of Limerick but never held an independent field command again.There was an early rumour among the Scottish victors that Sir John Cope had overslept on the morning of the battle although it inspired the rousing bagpipe tune Hey, Johnnie Cope, Are Ye Waking Yet , that version of events is not true.Then there was a story that although Prince Charles had spent the night before the battle on duty with his men, Cope had slept at comfortable quarters in Cockenzie.This tale was reported by the Edinburgh historian Robert Chambers as early as , although Copersquos  biographer Sir Robert Cadell found it yet another calumny: in spite of the assertions of Chambers and others, Cope had slept with his troops on the battlefield, as veried by the Culloden Papers and the Proceedings of Copersquos court martial.In his  biography of Prince Charles, the mischievous W. Drummond Norie lsquoimprovedrsquo the old legend further, claiming that Cope had been spending the night at a comfortable house in Cockenzie, nowadays referred to as the lsquoInk Bottlersquo and pictured in his book. This story was widely believed at the time.On June , , The Scotsman newspaper wrote that: ldquoIn Cockenzie several properties have been medically condemned and after a long allowance of time these have been closed amongst others portions of the historic Ink Bottle [Copersquos House].But the old house survived this crisis, however, being featured and photographed in the Edinburgh Evening News of August , , as a curious reminder of the hapless English generalrsquos efforts in the Battle of Prestonpans.The Cockenzie and Port Seton chronicler Dr R. Turner, writing in , rightly puts the curiously shaped old Ink Bottle house in or near Cope Lane in Port Seton, not far from the Old Parish Church Manse, adding that it had recently been demolished.I have been snooping round these parts to very this fact: the Ink Bottle is no longer standing, having fallen victim to the vandals of the s.Some historical revisionists from south of the Border have belatedly tried to save Sir John Copersquos reputation: the expedition to Inverness was caused by the bad advice he was given by some Scottish renegade noblemen, and the defeat at Prestonpans was wholly due to the poor quality of the soldiery.As we know, the story of him deserting his troops the morning of the battle is not true, but he did leave his military chest containing his papers and pound, for soldierrsquos pay under a staircase at Cockenzie House, where it was gleefully seized by the Prince and his men.It had been Copersquos decision to leave Edinburgh exposed, and it had been his responsibility to make sure the troops were properly trained and ably officered.The headlong flight to Berwick-upon-Tweed does not inspire confidence either, since it had been his duty to try his utmost to rally the troops, even at the cost of his own le.As a result of Sir John Cope being recalled, the Auld Enemy made sure that more canny officers, and tougher soldiers recalled from the Continent, were brought to Scotland to suppress the Rising: this target was achieved, just as planned, by lsquoButcherrsquo Cumberland at Culloden in .

title: charity-golf-day-musselburgh-golf-club-raises-1-000-maggies
story: Each year, players gather at Musselburgh Golf Club at Monktonhall to play for the Norrie Hosie Friday Cup.The tournament has grown from small beginnings, when local man NormanHosie Senior, from Stoneybank, began playing with friends back in the s.He donated a trophy for the match, the organisation of which has been taken over by his son Norrie Junior, from Wallyford, who has attracted sponsors for the event, which raises hundreds of pounds for charity each year, including Alzheimer Scotland, Royal Hospital for Children  Young People, and Changes, a Musselburgh-based community health project.This year, Mr Hosie Jnr decided to donate the money to Maggiersquos Edinburgh at the Western General Hospital, which helped him and his we Shirley after her breast cancer diagnosis last November.About  golfers took part in the recent competition, which was won by Alister Gray and raised pound for the charity. Since then, more donations have been forthcoming, taking the total to pound,.Norman said that Shirley underwent surgery in January and, after a three-week recovery period, she started four months of chemotherapy. After another three-week break, she began a month of radiotherapy.ldquoThis all finished in July this year and my we still has three years of bone treatments to do, one every six months, Norman said.ldquoShirley is now recovering from it all and doing well but has a long way to go before getting the all clear. All this was done through this yearrsquos Covid- pandemic and what great help and support came from the surgeons, nurses and consultants from the Western General Hospital. We canrsquot thank them enough.ldquoWe were told to go to visit Maggiersquos for further help and support as we started the process of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. They bent backwards to help us, offering one to one talks with us together and separately. They were so good at understanding what we were going through. We cannot praise the support specialists enough. As soon as we walked in the door of Maggiersquos, we were made so welcome ndash it was like we had known them for years.ldquoI think going to Maggiersquos did help face your fears. They listened to you and understood how you were feeling. They said it was normal to have bad days but not to beat yourself up when you had days like that. Maggiersquos gave you that sense of understanding what you were going through. They were so helpful, it is a place to go to for support, help, understanding and calm.ldquoI would say to anyone going through anything similar that you go to Maggiersquos for support, help and professional advice. They are so warm and welcoming to the patients and their families.He also thanked Musselburgh Golf Club for its organisation of the charity day and the sponsors, including Tony Rayfield, of Edinburgh Hometyre, and David McKay, from Direct Gardens.Mark Cooper, fundraising manger at Maggiersquos Edinburgh, said: ldquoEveryone at Maggiersquos is hugely appreciative to Norman and his friends for choosing to support Maggiersquos Edinburgh at their annual charity golf day.ldquoWe rely entirely on voluntary donations to operate and the demand for our services and complexity of the work we do has increase signicantly over the past  months.

title: work-taking-place-upgrade-drift-path-musselburgh-wallyford
story: Wimpey East Scotland said the improvements to the walkway, next to its Almond Park development at Pinkie, got under way last Wednesday and would take about four to five weeks to complete.A new surfaced path will be laid three metres in width to ensure it is fully accessible for a range of users.The section of pathway, which extends from the car park at Pinkie Terrace in Musselburgh to the underpass at the railway line, will also benefit from new street lighting which will be installed.There is no access to The Drt during the work in the interests of health and safety, the company stressed.Pauline Mills, land  planning director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: ldquoWe do hope these path improvement works will be welcomed locally and we apologise in advance for any inconvenience they may experience while the current path is closed to all users.ldquoAn information postcard will be distributed to all properties within the Almond Park development this week to let them know about the work that will be taking place.ldquoShould anyone have any concerns, please email sarah.patonbutler@taylorwimpey

title: msp-praises-volunteer-centre-critical-lifeline-visit
story: The comments follow South Scotland MSP Craig Hoyrsquos visit to the Tranent-based facility.The centre is a third-sector interface which provides support to voluntary organisations across East Lothian through partnership projects.This has included working in partnership with Musselburgh-based Paragon Products to deliver cleaning supplies to support the opening of community and third-sector organisations.During his visit, Mr Hoy met with the centrersquos chief officer Maureen Allan, discussing some of the challenges and opportunities the easing of lockdown restrictions had presented for the voluntary sector.The High Street facility also operates a childrenrsquos befriending service, supported hospital discharge programme, community taskforce service for those isolated during lockdown, a free community pantry and provides access to computers for those who struggle with technology.Working with East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities team, the countyrsquos health and social care partnership and other third-sector organisations in the county, the volunteer centre provides free, confidential advice and support for residents and support for small local third-sector groups.Mr Hoy said: ldquoVolunteer Centre East Lothian has become an essential service for many residents and organisations during this dficult period. The staff and volunteers are a critical leline for local residents.ldquoI would like to extend my thanks to Maureen for welcoming me to the centre and for her wider work fundraising.Maureen said: ldquoOur communities, the third sector and statutory partners have shown how much can be achieved by working together. The pandemic made a lot of people re-evaluate their lives. Many residents volunteered their time and it was great to see the real community spirit that has been lost over the years resurface.To contact the centre, call  , email info@volunteereastlothian.org.uk or visit volunteereastlothian.org.uk

title: auction-big-hare-trail-statues-raises-115-000-leuchie-house
story: The grand auction of the  sculptures took place at the towns Marine Hotel to raise money for the respite care centre on the outskirts of North Berwick.The hares, commissioned to mark Leuchiersquos th anniversary as an independent charity, delighted people of all ages as part of the The Big Hare Trail this summer.And they were in high demand as generous bidders dug deep to support the work of Leuchie, which provides expert care and a holiday experience to people affected by neurological conditions such as MS, stroke and MND.One of the most popular giant statues was lsquoHare Tae Golfrsquo, which was found at the West Links, having earlier made a cameo at The Renaissance during the Scottish Open.Chris Rutterfordrsquos eye-catching creation was sold for pound, ndash one of five hares that went to new homes for five-figure bids.As well as the  hares that featured on this yearrsquos trail, a blank lsquoMystery Harersquo went under the hammer at the end of the auction for pound,, and one of the artists will complete a bespoke edition for the successful bidder.Broadcaster Glenn Campbell, host for the evening, said: ldquoCongratulations to all the lucky bidders and Leuchie has asked me to pass on a very sincere thank you for your support."To put this into perspective, this funding could pay the salaries of four specialist nurses for an entire calendar year.Thanking the local businesses who sponsored the hares, he added: ldquoThis all began with a leap of faith that was taken by a number of businesses and organisations to sponsor The Big Hare Trail in the midst of a pandemic."Without these sponsors, this event would not have been possible."Stephen Pearson, chair of Leuchie House, said: ldquoThe hare trail has also been an ambitious project and, as we celebrate our th birthday this year, the board and the team are ambitious to do more, for more people, in the years ahead.Graeme Scougall, from Paisley, a regular guest at Leuchie, was one of the guests of honour on the night. Graeme was diagnosed with MS six years ago at the age of .Lana Bambridge, Leuchiersquos head of fundraising and development, said: ldquoWersquore pleased that the hares have captured the hearts of the local community."Every penny raised from the auction will help us to continue to support families who are in desperate need of a break from caring, especially in the wake of the pandemic.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-time-watch
story: The Scottish government came under fire when people reported problems using the NHSScotland Covid Status App after its release on Thursday.Vaccine passports is just one of a number of changes introduced over the past seven days, with new travels rules coming into effect from Monday.Scotland announced last month that it would maintain a four nation approach to travel despite initial hesitancy to do so.It means that the same rules apply to international travel wherever in the UK you are visiting.Heres everything you need to know about todays update including what the first minister might say...Nicola Sturgeons Covid update will take place today at around :pm.The exact timing of the announcement will depend on the previous three items on the agenda running to time.You can watch the first ministers Covid update on Scottish ParliamentTV.Alternatively it will be streamed live on the Scottish governments social media s and the SNP will live tweet the statement.The briefing will also be broadcast live on the BBC Scotland channel from :pm.The first minister will as always provide an update on the figures, as well as the progress in vaccination.She is als likely to touch on the implementation of the vaccine passport scheme and perhaps the new status app.Following Nicola Sturgeons statement there will be a ministerial update on the Covid Recovery Strategy, so the first minister may indicate in her speech what this strategy may include.

title: north-berwick-home-branded-grand-designs-experiment-approved
story: Architect Robin Sutherland saw his vision of a family home on North Berwickrsquos High Street turned down by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee.The proposals, recommended for approval by planning officers, were rejected by a single vote.Mr Sutherland, who works in the town, appealed to Scottish Ministers to see the plans given the green light.Rosie Leven, the reporter appointed by the Scottish Ministers, gave the planned three-storey building at  High Street and land to the north the go ahead.Neighbours overlooking the proposed three-bedroom house had objected to the planned property, which measures just over four metres wide and  metres long, on the grounds of privacy.Mrs Leven attached a condition to the approval that a balustrade should be included on the roof terrace.She said: ldquoI consider that the proposed first floor kitchen doors and roof terrace are part of the main living space of the proposed house and are likely to be more regularly used, during a larger proportion of the day, than the bedroom windows.ldquoI consider that it is from those first floor windows spaces that there is the greatest potential for an adverse effect on neighbouring residential amenity.ldquoIn this respect, the appellant has suggested that a condition could be placed on the consent to require a . metre balustrade around the three open sides of the roof terrace.ldquoIn the circumstances, I find that such a balustrade would help to reduce the ability for overlooking, both from the roof terrace itself and from the double doors to the kitchen.ldquoTaking this into account, I accept that there may be some overlooking from and to the proposed bedroom window, but with the addition of a balustrade, I consider that the overall impact on the amenity of the neighbouring properties would not be signicantly adverse.Concerns had also been raised about whether the proposed building was in keeping with the character of the town centre.The Reporter noted that traditional buildings ldquodominate the area but added ldquothere are dferent heights and styles of building.She said there was ldquono consistent building line on Forth Street and the character is one of buildings offset from each other, providing interesting views and angles.The proposals originally went before the local authorityrsquos planning committee in January, with six of the  councillors voting to reject the plans.Councillor Jane Henderson was joined by fellow North Berwick Coastal ward members Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay in speaking out against the plans.She told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements television show presented by Kevin McCloud where unique and daringly designed homes are built.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-learned-announcement
story: Covid cases in Scotland have fallen in recent weeks, which is due immune response fromboth vaccination and an element of people being infected with Covid, according to the first minister.The Scottish government was criticised last week after many people had problems with downloading the NHS Scotland Covid Status app.Changes to the rules surroundinginternational travel also came into force as Scotland chose to participate in a four nations approach.It means that the same rules will apply wherever you travel in the UK.As Scotland continues its journey towardspost pandemic recovery, heres what we learned from Nicola SturgeonsCovid update today...The first minister confirmed that there would be no changes to the "albeit, limited regulations" still in place in Scotland.This is because, according to the first minister, the numbers have continued to fall.However, she also said that despite falling cases, the infection rate still remainsrelatively high which is of concern as we head into the winter months.It is for this reason that the current limited measures, such as mask wearing,will remain in place in Scotland.Explaining this, the first minister said: "the level of infection, though falling, remains relatively high and so we consider that it is prudent at this stage, as we approach winter, to keep in place the remaining mitigations, face coverings for example, for a further period."A total of , daily cases were recordedtoday, a slight increase on yesterdays figures which were below ,.The "signicant and sustained fall" in cases is now being reflected in the number of hospital admissions, according to the first minister.As a result, Nicola Sturgeon continues to remainoptimistic about the general downward trend in numbers, following a period of daily figures topping , throughout August and early September.Describing this as a relief, she said: "Given that cases are continuing to fall, we hope and expect that the number of people in hospital will decline further. We also expect that the number of people dying from Covid will reduce."The mitigation measures currently in place in schools areunder review, particularly whether pupils will continue to have to wear masks in schools after the October break.The body conducting the review is expected to come to a decision on such measures later this afternoon and will then advise the Scottish government.The first minister added that"should they advise that any easing is possible following the October half-term, the Scottish Government will consider this carefully and advise schools of any changes as soon as possible."Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged the problems releated to the app, particularly the issues downloading vaccination status on Thursday and Friday, and apologised.Explaining the source of the problem, the first minister said:"Essentially the high level of demand after the launch of the app ndash combined with an error in one part of the NHS system ndash meant that information wasnrsquot being sent quickly enough from the NHS system to the app."She added: "Indeed, I can report that the initial backlog of people waiting for their information to be matched had been cleared by Saturday lunchtime."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that although initially the app faced signicant problems, it now works well.She therefore encouraged everyone to download or order their vaccine passport as soon as possible.

title: insurers-cover-distressed-dogs-owners-return-office
story: With many people working from home during the pandemic, many new pets were purchased due to the excess time at home. But now most people are ing to the office, and pets are not used to being left alone.Pet owners may not realise that their insurance policy could include cover for veterinary treatment for their distressed pets, financial information firm Defaqto said.Behaviour cover is designed to pay for therapy to treat emotional distress which could be caused by separation anxiety now that some owners are no longer working from home.Defaqto found more insurers are now offering behaviour cover as part of their pet insurance products, compared with the start of the coronavirus pandemic.Nearly half of dog insurance policies now include full cover for behaviour, compared with % in February .Defaqto cautioned that insurers will exclude cover for claims where the behavioural illness could have been prevented by proper training and socialising.Brian Brown, consumer finance expert at Defaqto, said: ldquoDogs provided much-needed companionship for their owners throughout the pandemic and for those that started le in lockdown, they have never known any dferent.ldquoIt is not surprising then that some dogs are anxious when they are being left alone for the first time and displaying destructive behaviour. The good news is that this is treatable and insurers have stepped up to increase their cover for this.ldquoMany insurers offer free vet helplines where you can get advice over the phone, evenyou donrsquot have to make a claim. If you find you donrsquot have insurance cover, speak to the animal charities to get advice.

title: scotland-v-israel-many-times-teams-played-track-record
story: It comes as Steve Clarkes side continues their quest to qualy for Quatar , after playing in their first major international tournament in -years at the Euros earlier this summer.With the crowd behind them at a packed Hampden stadium, Scotland will look to extend their current lead over Israel in the Group F table.Although its the Scots whocurrently hold second place, Israel is only one point behind meaning everything is to play for in Saturdays match.The good news is that a home gamehas previously proved advantageous inhead to heads, and with the biggest crowd expected at Hampden since , the team certainly wont be short of support.Heres what you need to know about the teamsprevious matches and Scotlands track record against Israel...Since October  , Scotland has played Israel six times, with Saturdays match the seventh in almost exactly three years.Prior to , the teams had not met since the s, when they played twice in  and once in .Of the six matches in the past three years, Scotland has won two of the games.The first triumph came in the UEFA Nations League on November  , when Scotland won - at Hampden in front of a ,-strong crowd.A draw behind closed doors in the same league came next in September , closely followed by a win on penalties one month later during the UEFA European Championships qualiers.Israels wins came at their home grounds on October   and November  .With another head to head incoming, Saturdays match is not the first time the teams have faced each other in this tournament they played in Tel Aviv on March  , drawing -.

We also expect that the number of people dying from Covid will reduce."The mitigation measures currently in place in schools areunder review, particularly whether pupils will continue to have to wear masks in schools after the October break.The body conducting the review is expected to come to a decision on such measures later this afternoon and will then advise the Scottish government.The first minister added that"should they advise that any easing is possible following the October half-term, the Scottish Government will consider this carefully and advise schools of any changes as soon as possible."Nicola Sturgeon acknowledged the problems related to the app, particularly the issues downloading vaccination status on Thursday and Friday, and apologised.Explaining the source of the problem, the first minister said:"Essentially the high level of demand after the launch of the app ndash combined with an error in one part of the NHS system ndash meant that information wasnrsquot being sent quickly enough from the NHS system to the app."She added: "Indeed, I can report that the initial backlog of people waiting for their information to be matched had been cleared by Saturday lunchtime."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that although initially the app faced signicant problems, it now works well.She therefore encouraged everyone to download or order their vaccine passport as soon as possible.

title: christmas-shortages-2021-homemade-christmas-gift-ideas
story: Covid- and Brexit are among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas...The festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipes can be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .Christmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - with people using the same items year after year, and even generation after generation, this could be your opportunity to leave your stamp on celebrations for decades to come.There are plenty of ideas online, but why not buy some cheap, clear plastic or glass bobbles which you can decorate with permanent markers, tippex pens or paint, before tying with ribbon.Baked salt dough can work just as well, while simple origami folding techniques can be used to transform a piece of paper into something special.A photo album filled with memories could be the best present someone ever receives.It may be slightly time consuming, but a collection of photos reminding your loved ones of a special time in their le is a timeless classic which will never get old.Photo albums can be cheaply purchasedonline or in store - charity shops are a good place to start - and companies like Free Printsmean you can order photographs for free from your phone.If you are a keen knitter, homemade socks are guaranteed to please as well as keep people warm through the cold winter months.Sloe gin is synonymous with aChristmas tipple, and as it turns out its pretty easy to make yourself, with some recipes only requiring three ingredients.Again, start saving bottles and by December you will be ready to decant.You cant go wrong with some Christmas baking, whether it be mince pies, yule logs or mini Christmas puddings.Pop it in a box and tie with ribbon and you have yourself the perfect gt which will go down a treat while people wait for Christmas dinner.If you dont want to give physical gts, you could make a voucher for an experience to take your loved one out for coffee or dinner once the festive season is over.Its something to look forward to once Christmas is over, and gives you a chance to catch up on each others lives after the busy end-of-year period.

story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: mary-continis-recipe-blueberry-pear-loaf-cake
story: This moist delicious yoghurt loaf cake is a homage to this autumn bountyhellipand no, I didnrsquot pinch the pears!Ingredients:g unsalted butter, room temperatureg soft brown or caster sugar large free- range eggsg thick Greek style yoghurtJuice and zest of  unwaxed lemong ginger in syrup or crystallised ginger, chopped into small piecesg self ndash raising flour, sted tablespoon milkPinch of saltg blaeberries,  unripe pearsFor topping tablespoons demerara or granulated sugar teaspoons cinnamonIcing sugar for final dustingMethod:Pre-heat oven C   Gas  kg loaf tin, Grease and line the baking tin, leaving the greaseproof paper longer at the sides to allowyou to lt the baked cake out of the tin rather than turn it upside down.Beat the butter and g soft brown or caster sugar together until light and fluffy.Whisk the eggs separately with a fork and add gradually to the butter mix.Whisk in the Greek yoghurt, lemon juice, zest and the pieces of chopped ginger.Now add the sted flour, the salt and the milk and carefully blend everything together toform a thick better.Use a large spoon to gently fold in the berries.Pour into the greased baking tin.Core the pears and cut into slices and then quarters. Decorate the top of the cake leaving the pear pieces sticking out of the batter.Bake in the middle of the oven for  minutes.Mix the demerara sugar and cinnamon together.Remove the cake and scatter the sugar topping across the surface.Bake for a further - minutes until the top is firm and a skewer pushed into the middlecomes out clean. It is a very moist cake benefits from being well cooked. Make sure you arechecking the cake and not the moisture from the pears.Remove from the oven and leave to cool in the tin for  minutes or so.Use the over- hanging greaseproof paper to lt the cake out of the tin and onto a wire rack to cool completely.Serve with Greek yoghurt or swirls of indulgent whipped double cream.Mary Contini OBE is a writer and Director of Valvona  Crolla ltd. title: folk invited to walk through islands deal proposals for world heritage site
story: Community views are being sought on options for the future management of the Heart of Neolithic Orkney World Heritage Site , which includes Skara Brae, Ring of Brodgar, Stones of Stenness and Maeshowe chambered tomb.Next week, there will be an opportunity for folk to get an inside view of proposals, during in-person consultation sessions in Kirkwall and Stenness.Known as the Orkney Gateway Programme, the proposals aim to provide a more in-depth experience for visitors from home and away across the WHS and generate opportunities for Orkney folk through a more responsible and sustainable approach to tourism.The programme proposes improved signage, technology to monitor visitor numbers in real time and apps to suggest alternative attractions. Proposals also include “active travel” routes, e-bike chargers and welcome facilities, alongside coach permits and charging at some car parks.The programme is being funded with joint investment of up to £. million from the Scottish Government and UK Government, as part of the Islands Growth Deal — a ten-year investment programme jointly funded by the UK and Scottish governments, the three island councils and their partners from the public, academic and business sectors.During the in-person sessions, due to take place next Tuesday and Wednesday, attendees will be guided through proposals with representatives from project partners.OIC leader, Councillor James Stockan, said: “The Islands Deal commitment we have from the Scottish and UK Governments to support the Orkney Gateway is hugely gratying and reflects the position our World Heritage Site holds as one of the jewels in Scotland’s and indeed the UK’s tourism crown — not to mention the global archaeological signicance of the site.“But we must remember that at the core of this is a landscape and series of monuments which for many Orcadians is a direct, mysterious and powerful link to their past. And we know equally they are held very dear by people who’ve moved into these islands over the years.“So, as partners, we are all very clear that we want to gather local people’s views on the range of options that we could bid for through our final Islands Deal business case.”The consultation events are scheduled for Tuesday, October , at Maeshowe Visitor Centre, Stenness, from pm to pm, and Wednesday, October , at St Magnus Centre, Kirkwall, from pm until pm.If you’re unable to attend these events, further information is available at www.orkney.gov.uk orkneygateway. Comments can be emailed to worldheritage@orkney.gov.uk or posted to Orkney World Heritage Site Gateway Consultation, Development and Infrastructure, Orkney Islands Council, Council Offices, Kirkwall, Orkney KW NY.The closing date for feedback is October  at pm.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: information session to showcase self driving vehicles
story: Folk are to be able to find out more about a pilot project exploring the use of autonomous — or self-driving — vehicles .An information session is due to take place at the Orkney Research and Innovation Campus in Stromness next week, Thursday, October .The trial is one of four pilot projects running in the North Sea region as part of the Planning for Autonomous Vehiclesproject, which will explore how autonomous vehicles could interact with existing modes of transport.Folk will have the opportunity to learn more about the trials, see the vehicles that will be used and learn more about the potential applications of AV technologies.The event takes place at ORIC — the former Stromness Primary School — from pm to pm and there is no need to book.In Orkney, small AVs will undergo initial trials for logistics and freight purposes, such as the transport of general supplies, luggage, parcels, waste and other goods.These AVs will move at walking pace and work is ongoing to identy a shortlist of potential routes and uses.In a larger scale project in Inverness, an AV passenger service will be provided between Inverness Campus and Inverness Retail and Business Park. Safety is paramount and although the vehicle used will be capable of driving itself, a driver will be present at all times to take controlrequired.Widespread use of self-driving vehicles is expected by next decade and the findings of the project will be used to determine how countries across Europe can effectively implement them # including considering how they fit in with green transport and spatial planning strategies, as well as likely socio-economic impacts.Representatives from the project partners will be in attendance including HITRANS , More Work Less Carbon — a company based in Utrecht, Netherlands, who will supply the AVs — and Robert Gordon University.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: taster session to be held for paralympic sport
story: A free taster session is on Monday night to mark National Boccia Day.Bocciais a Paralympic sport with no Olympic equivalent and is similar to bowls.The game is played on a flat, smooth surface, usually indoors, with a court the size of a badminton court.It#s a mixed-gender sport that can be played inidually or as a team. Although it#s designed for people with a disability, anyone can play and a classication system operates at competitive level so that players compete at a similar level of ability.From a seated position, players propel balls to land as close as possible to a white marker ball, known as the Jack. Two sides compete as iniduals, pairs or as a team of three over a set number of ends.Each side plays six ballseach end. After each end, the athlete, pair or team with the ball closest to the jack receives one point plus an additional point for each ball closer to the jack than their opponent#s.Points are accumulated over the course of a match to find a winner. Although simple to get started, the tactics of the sport offer both tension and excitement as the game plays out.The session will be held at KGS Sports Centre, .pm–.pm.Contact Joanne Cairns to book or for more information on , ext , or joanne.cairns@orkney.gov.uk.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: wind farm bid announced for west of orkney site
story: A major Scottish consortium has announced a bid for an offshore wind project west of Orkney.The two-gigawatt proposal – named the West of Orkney Windfarm – has the potential to power more than two million homes and is currently being assessed by the Crown Estate Scotland.The consortium of Macquarie’s Green Investment Group, TotalEnergies and Scottish developer RIDG, has been engaging with stakeholders in Orkney and Caithness for five years. This includes Memorandums of Understanding with Orkney Harbour Authority and Scrabster Harbour Trust to enhance port infrastructure and position the area more competitively to support offshore wind projects in the future.The announcement of this bid comes after the completion of the leasing round of Scotwind, a programme which will lease areas of the seabed around Scotland for wind farm developments.The Scottish Government hopes that as much as ten gigawatts of new generating capacity will be built over the next decade.Stephen Kerr, project director of the West of Orkney Windfarm, said: “While ScotWind has created the opportunity for a global industry to tap into Europe’s best wind resource, our consortium believes that success will be driven by targeted proposals built upon strong local relationships.”We have designed our bid specically around this location and brought together a unique combination of stakeholders to maximise the opportunities for the region.“In particular, the upcoming round of offshore wind projects are a terric opportunity for ports in Caithness and Orkney to win signicant long-term contracts in the installation and operational phase of these major infrastructure schemes.“Our agreements with Scrabster Harbour Trust and Orkney Harbour Authority will enable us to work together with a clear focus on long term delivery. Each port has its own specic capabilities and attributes, and on successful site award we have committed to fund collaborative design and supply studies and to invest where appropriate in improving each harbour’s infrastructure.“We will apply a similar collaborative approach across the supply chain, working closely with Scottish and UK suppliers to deliver on climate targets and enhance local economies.”The consortium has undertaken extensive site investigations, including birds, marine mammals and near-shore geophysical surveys, and has finalised a grid connection agreement with National Grid that will enable the project to commence generation in .Jim Buck, harbourmaster for Orkney Harbour Authority, said that Scapa Flow # the second largest natural harbour in the world # offers an environment like no other and said that the £million masterplan to develop ports around Orkney is key in attracting new business to the islands. “Our Masterplan embraces decarbonisation and a transition away from fossil fuels,” said Mr Buck.“It includes a range of infrastructure enhancements across key locations around the Orkney mainland, including a new deep-water facility in Scapa Flow, which will be crucial to us realising our ambition to deliver social and economic benefit from offshore wind energy.“The West of Orkney Windfarm is ideally positioned to make signicant use of these future facilities and this collaboration represents another key step on our journey to position Orkney as a base for innovation and a major contributor in delivering a carbon-free future for the islands.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: shetland star unveils plaque in his name
story: TV star Douglas Henshall has today unveiled a plaque in his name as a thanks from Shetland for the success of the namesake TV series and the boost it has given tourism.The plaque was unveiled by Mr Henshall in the road outside his fictional home in the show, The Lodberries, a site that has become one of pilgrimage for fans of the series who visit.He was joined by Steve Mathieson, VisitScotland development manager and Malcolm Bell, Convener of Shetland Islands Council. said: #I don’t think anyone could have guessed when we first came here that Shetland would become such a loved show that it would tempt people from all over the globe to come and see for themselves the beauty of this place.#It’s been our privilege to come and work here for the last  years and for our work to be commemorated in this way by VisitScotland and Shetland Islands Council is both wonderfully surprising and genuinely touching.”, out Friday.A Shetland poet has had work included in a national virtual exhibition after being chosen from hundreds of entries.
